qas.question: What do NPOs in South Africa give to their donors?
What can a tax certificate issued by a South Africian NPO be used for?

answers.text: a tax deduction by the donor

qas.question: Where are South Africian NPOs registered?

answers.text: Companies and Intellectual Property Commission as Nonprofit Companies (NPCs)

qas.question: Who keeps track of the trusts of South Africian NPOs?
Who would a South Africian NPO register with if they were a voluntary organization?
What does Master of the High Court issue to donors?
What group must all donors be registered with?
What can a tax certificate be used for when requested by the Master of the High Court?
What are trusts able to voluntarily register with?
Who can use a tax certificate when its issued by the Master of the High Court?

context: In South Africa, charities issue <a0_0><b5_0>a tax certificate<b5_0/><a0_0/> when requested by donors which can be used as <a1_0><b7_0>a tax deduction<b7_0/> by <b9_0>the donor<b9_0/><a1_0/>. Non Profit Organisations are registered under <a2_0>Companies and Intellectual Property Commission as Nonprofit Companies (NPCs)<a2_0/> but may voluntarily register with <b8_0>The Nonprofit Companies Directorate<b8_0/>. Trusts are registered by the <a3_0>Master of the High Court<a3_0/>. Section 21 Companies are registered under the Company's Act. All are classified as Voluntary Organisations and all must be registered with <b6_0>the <a4_0>South Africa Revenue Services "SARS"<b6_0/><a4_0/>.[citation needed]
